data.title: VPU ETF: Tech Commitments Could Boost The Utility Sector
data.description:
Vanguard Utilities Index Fund ETF (VPU) is delivering strong performance since the beginning of the year thanks to the continued growth in electricity demand from data center infrastructure. Since my previous coverage last November, the fund delivered a 5.8% total return, and I believe that VPU has the potential of up to 10% further gains. My previous article highlighted that the inconsistency between the artificial intelligence expansion and the ramp-up timing of the power generation capacity is sharpening up as the major hyperscalers are already experiencing power undersupply. The inconsistency is more than clear, and the government will now require data center operators to pay for their electricity needs. This could strengthen the investment commitments and collaborations between technology and utility players, boosting the development of the national power grid with accompanying generation capacity. Hence, I would like to reaffirm my bullish stance on the VPU ETF, as the favorable power demand profile could strengthen the sector's earnings growth and dividend yield.

Fund Overview

Vanguard Utilities ETF is established to provide an exposure to the American utility sector, including stocks of companies engaged in the distribution of electricity, water, or gas, or that operate as independent power producers.

The fund’s sector allocation didn’t change since my previous coverage, betting mainly on electric utilities (61.7% share) and multi-utilities (24.3% share). The ETF preserves its concentrated position around the top 5 holdings, which account for nearly 35.2% of the portfolio and are distributed as follows: NextEra Energy, Inc. (NEE) with 12.2% (vs 10.4% in the previous writing); The Southern Company (SO) with 6.4% (vs 6.7%); Duke Energy Corporation (DUK) with 6.4% (unchanged); Constellation Energy Corporation (CEG) with 5.9% (vs 6.9%); and American Electric Power Company, Inc. (AEP) with 4.3% share, which pushed Vistra Corp. (VST) from the key 5 positions.

The expense ratio is very low (0.09% per annum), while total net assets under management approximate $10 billion.

Since the beginning of the year, the utility sector has been delivering very impressive performance, especially compared with the technology sector and broad market. The VPU ETF recorded a 10.1% total return, which is slightly below its main alternative, the Utilities Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLU), due to the less concentrated positions and a more diversified basis of utility exposure. At the same time, the technology sector has marked a 2.5% loss, while the broad market is up by hardly 1% year to date.

The performance gap between utilities and technology stocks could be explained by the recent development in the artificial intelligence industry. On the one hand, the utility sector is benefiting from the rapid development of the AI infrastructure, which drives a significant increase in electricity demand. On the other hand, the main technology players are feeling the pressure from the AI frenzy, as investors are increasingly concerned over the unprecedented surge in AI CapEx and the potential returns on data center investments.

It’s becoming clear that the current power generation capacity is not keeping up with the AI infrastructure expansion. Meanwhile, the industry is going through favorable regulatory developments, where the newly negotiated rate protection pledge would require major technology companies developing artificial intelligence data centers to cover their own electricity needs. As a result, this could significantly increase investments from tech giants into power generation sources.

OpenAI (OPENAI) already announced that it will pay for the costs of developing energy-related infrastructure required by its Stargate data centers by paying for additional infrastructure to support local energy grids or secure its own energy supply. At the same time, Amazon.com, Inc. (AMZN), Microsoft Corporation (MSFT), Alphabet Inc. (GOOGL), Meta Platforms, Inc. (META) have already collectively invested in the development of several gigawatts of new power. The industrial sector may become an additional driver of energy consumption growth. Reports say that Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited (TSM) may invest an additional $100 billion in its U.S. chip manufacturing facilities, bringing its total investment commitments up to $265 billion and making the company one of the biggest investors ever in America.

Apart from this, the need to replace aging power infrastructure could capitalize additional investments. For reference, the largest grid operator, PJM Interconnection, has approved an $11.8 billion transmission expansion plan to keep up with surging data center connection requests across its footprint. This is especially relevant as the combined capital expenditures of the main hyperscalers are expected to top $650 billion in 2026, dedicated mainly to data center infrastructure. For comparison, the U.S. energy utilities are projected to invest $222 billion in 2026. This represents only a fraction of that going to the data centers, underlining the fact that there is substantial room for expansion in the utility companies.

Hence, this represents a positive scenario for the utility sector, as the rising energy consumption for AI infrastructure stimulates capital investment expansion by the utility operators. The growth of investments could boost the utilities' rate base, which creates conditions for higher revenue requirements, earnings growth, and dividend distributions.

Future Potential

For the calculations of the VPU future upside potential, I will use the same weighted average target prices approach. According to the analyst estimates, VPU ETF has a 6.3% capital gain potential over the next 12-month horizon. Taking into account the forward DPS estimates, the total return of VPU ETF could be estimated at 9%, which makes me reaffirm my Buy recommendation on the fund.

Taking a closer look, we can notice that the largest part of the estimated upside potential should come from Vistra Energy, Constellation Energy, PG&E Corp (PCG), Duke Energy, and NRG Energy, Inc. (NRG). In particular, Vistra could benefit from its 2.6GW natural gas asset acquisition, the 20-year PPA at Comanche Peak NPP, and plans to develop two gas-fired units in West Texas. Constellation stands among the main beneficiaries of the data center electricity demand surge, since the company operates the largest fleet of nuclear power facilities with a total nameplate capacity of close to 28GW. PG&E has a strong 5-year capital plan of $73 billion through 2030, which stipulates an average annual rate base growth of 9% and EPS growth of at least 9%. In addition, the California utility adds 2GW of projects in final engineering from last quarter, up to almost 3.6GW. Going forward, Duke Energy operates the second largest nuclear portfolio in the U.S. with 10GW in total capacity and has the largest fully regulated capital plan in the industry of $103 billion spanning over 5 years, which has the potential to drive up to a 7% long-term EPS growth rate. NRG Energy, in turn, targets a strong 14% annual growth in adjusted EPS and FCF through 2030, effectively doubling its generation capacity to 25GW following the closure of the LS Power transaction.

Looking at the earnings estimates, the utility sector could register 8.4% earnings growth in the first quarter of 2026, compared to 2.7% blended growth so far in Q4. Moreover, the EPS growth is expected to accelerate during the year, which indicates strong dividend flow potential. In addition, the target interest rate is anticipated to drop by 50 bps over the next 12-month horizon. This could alleviate the industry’s debt burden, strengthen earnings, and make the utilities dividend profile more appealing compared to the 10-year government bond yield.

As a result, I will reaffirm my bullish call on the VPU ETF, which has the potential for up to a 10% return over the next one-year period. I believe that the utility sector is one of the most prominent investment opportunities in 2026, powered by solid fundamentals behind energy demand growth from AI infrastructure and favorable regulatory support.

Risk Factors

Natural disasters remain a critical risk factor for utility sector infrastructure. For instance, Edison International (EIX) shares fell sharply in the beginning of last year amid massive wildfires in California, with ongoing investigations into whether faulty equipment at the company was involved in the fires. Meanwhile, with capital expenditures rising, the role of government regulation is increasing, as the ability to pass on additional costs to consumers depends on the regulator's position.

Conclusion

The rapid development of AI infrastructure is the main driving factor for the growth in the utility sector. The existing gap between data center electricity needs, which are growing exponentially, and the current capacity of the U.S. power grid is forcing utility operators to accelerate capital projects. An increased rate base strengthens utilities’ financial performance, which positively impacts earnings and dividend yield, increasing the investment attractiveness of the industry. Against this backdrop, I believe that VPU ETF is a reasonable investment with the potential to deliver up to a 10% return over a 1-year horizon.

data.title: A 12%+ Yield Trading For Pennies On The Dollar: Blue Owl Capital
data.description:
Blue Owl Capital Corporation (OBDC) is a BDC (BIZD) currently trading at an over 20% discount to its net asset value, even though the company just executed a third-party loan sale at book value that validates the methodology used by the third-party valuation firm that marks OBDC’s portfolio each quarter.

Thus, while the company trades at $11.58 as I write this, its NAV per share stands at $14.81 as of the end of last quarter. Given the company's healthy balance sheet and low non-accruals with healthy internal risk ratings, the core debate here is not whether OBDC can survive or not, but rather why the market is penalizing it to such a great degree. Yes, a dividend cut is likely, as we will discuss in this article, especially given that the Federal Reserve is expected to continue cutting rates this year and spreads stay quite tight in the industry.

In my view, the market has overreacted, and while I would not pay a one-times or greater NAV ratio on OBDC shares given the hefty fees that management charges and the headwinds that the industry faces, I think that the current discount to NAV looks far too wide, and therefore rate it a strong buy today.

Inside the Portfolio: Senior Secured Strength and Diversification

One of the most important aspects of the OBDC thesis is the state of its investment portfolio, as there have been a lot of fears raised in the media recently about the state of private credit, with UBS (UBS) forecasting up to 15% default rates in the near future. The market seems to be pricing this into OBDC right now, given its over 20% discount to NAV.

However, the fundamentals are actually quite strong, with the company having a 79% senior secured portfolio, with 73.1% of its debt invested in first-lien loans. Additionally, the portfolio is very well diversified with 234 companies across 30 industries, with its top 10 positions representing just 23% of its portfolio on a fair value basis.

The company also has significant joint venture and specialty finance investments that amount to about 12% of the portfolio, which are less exposed to falling base rates and have generated higher returns on equity over time, with over 14% ROEs based on management's commentary on the latest earnings call.

Taking a deeper look at the health of the portfolio, they have strong headline numbers with only 1.1% non-accruals at fair value and 2.3% at cost, which are competitive with many other BDCs out there. There's certainly been no indication of distress. Additionally, their internal risk ratings are pretty healthy, with 90.7% of the portfolio falling into an internal risk rating of 1 or 2 and only 1.4% of the portfolio falling at the riskiest level of either 4 or 5, which importantly is unchanged quarter over quarter and shows that they are unlikely to see a significant spike in non-accruals in the near term and are also at low risk of significant long-term capital losses based on the current state of their portfolio.

Buybacks, Balance Sheet Strength, and a BAA2 Upgrade

Management also has been buying back stock pretty aggressively recently, with $148 million worth of shares repurchased in Q4 alone, which delivered $0.05 per share in NAV accretion. For an externally managed BDC, that is a pretty noteworthy buyback and is being done at a discount that is creating significant value for shareholders.

On top of that, the company's balance sheet remains in solid shape with a 1.19 times debt-to-equity ratio, which is below their upper target limit of 1.25 times, and with $4.2 billion in total liquidity, as well as a weighted average debt maturity of 4.3 years. Moreover, Moody's just upgraded the company in January to Baa2, giving it one of the strongest credit ratings in the BDC space. That is an additional vote of confidence in the quality of OBDC's balance sheet and investment portfolio. The company's debt maturities are also well laddered, with maturities staggered nicely over the next several years and the vast majority of their debt not coming due until 2029 or later.

Dividend Cut Ahead?

Moving forward, we expect the company to face near-term net interest income headwinds from additional Federal Reserve rate cuts, continued loan repayments that they have to reinvest into new loans that are at less positive spreads, and them having to refinance some debt this year that has matured at interest rates that are materially lower than what they'll be able to refinance them at in the current market.

That being said, they can also repurchase shares, which should be accretive to both NAV and adjusted net investment income, and they're taking additional steps to try to reduce financing costs while also investing in specialty finance and joint venture opportunities that are less rate sensitive and have been generating very strong returns on equity. OBDC is also generating solid net investment income yields, with its most recent quarter posting an adjusted NII of $0.36 per share, which amounts to a 12.4% annualized adjusted NII yield on the current cost.

Overall, however, we expect the dividend to be cut this year due to the fact that the base dividend already exceeds the company's adjusted NII ($0.37 vs. $0.36), and that gap should only widen moving forward due to the aforementioned factors. That being said, it will probably only have to be cut by 10% to 20%, which, given the current yield, means that the dividend yield on current cost should remain above 10% this year. If the company decides to make a deeper cut to its base dividend than that, it will likely pay out substantial supplemental distributions, which would still bring the effective yield on cost to above 10%.

Meanwhile, if the company continues to lean into debt buybacks or share repurchases, that should help prop up NAV per share, especially if their underwriting performance remains solid. Management gave every indication that they plan to continue buying back stock as they expanded their authorization to $300 million. As management stated on the latest earnings call, they're,

going to actively look at comparing buying stock versus deploying capital into the market.

Additionally, insider buying has been quite strong in recent months, which indicates management's conviction in the portfolio area.

Risks Investors Cannot Ignore

Of course, OBDC does have risks to keep in mind. Not only could a dividend cut potentially reduce sentiment on the stock (though this has been happening across the BDC space, and it has not impacted shares much at all recently due to the floating rate nature of their underlying holdings, which I recently detailed here), there is also a risk of credit deterioration. Therefore, if internal risk ratings of 3 to 5, and especially 4 to 5, begin to spike, that could be a sign that the company's health is deteriorating markedly.

Additionally, OBDC does have exposure to software, with it making up 11.1% of its portfolio. Therefore, if software truly gets disrupted by AI, that could also weaken the company's underwriting portfolio. That said, OBDC takes precautions with its software lending and has an excellent track record in the sector, so I'm not too concerned about that. It is worth noting that management emphasized on the earnings call that the loan-to-value ratios on their software loans are in the 30%, which adds an additional margin of safety to that section of OBDC's portfolio.

Why the Market May Be Getting OBDC Completely Wrong

Overall, I believe that OBDC is likely headed for a dividend cut, but investors are still going to likely enjoy a double-digit yield on current cost while being able to buy shares at a huge discount to net asset value despite the company selling a substantial portion of its underlying loans in line with the marks that they received from the third-party valuation agency and also engaging in fairly substantial buybacks. It also trades at a much bigger discount than its historical average has been, and just last July it traded roughly in line with its NAV, despite its underlying fundamentals today being nearly identical to where they were then.

Thus, I think OBDC warrants a strong buy rating right now, especially given that it trades at a huge discount to sector peers like Ares Capital Corporation (ARCC), which has a similarly positioned portfolio and is putting up similar strong overall numbers, as I recently detailed here.

While it is not one of my very favorite BDCs at the moment, it is on my watch list for potential inclusion in my 7% to 8% yielding total return outperforming and below-market beta portfolio at High Yield Investor.
